title: Deuteronomy Chapter 27 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 27 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 27 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 27.

questions.question: What did Moses and the elders command the people to keep according to Deuteronomy 27:1?
options: All the commandments given that day
questions.correctAnswer: All the commandments given that day
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:1 states that Moses with the elders commanded the people to keep all the commandments which he commanded them that day.

questions.question: Where were the great stones to be set up and plaistered as commanded in Deuteronomy 27?
questions.correctAnswer: On Mount Ebal
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:4 commands that after crossing Jordan, the stones would be set up on Mount Ebal and plaistered.

questions.question: What was to be written on the stones according to Deuteronomy 27:3?
options: All the words of the law
questions.correctAnswer: All the words of the law
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:3 instructs that all the words of the law should be written on the stones after crossing Jordan.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 27:5, what kind of tool was forbidden to be used upon the altar stones?
questions.correctAnswer: Iron tool
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:5 clearly states that no iron tool should be lifted upon the altar stones.

questions.question: Who were to stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people as stated in Deuteronomy 27:12?
options: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, Benjamin
Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, Naphtali
questions.correctAnswer: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, Benjamin
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:12 lists these tribes as those who shall stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people.

questions.question: Which tribes were assigned to stand on Mount Ebal to curse according to Deuteronomy 27:13?
options: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, Naphtali
Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, Naphtali
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:13 specifies these tribes to stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 27:15, what is cursed?
options: Anyone who makes a graven or molten image and puts it in a secret place
Anyone who steals from his neighbor
questions.correctAnswer: Anyone who makes a graven or molten image and puts it in a secret place
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:15 states that the man who makes any graven or molten image and hides it is cursed.

questions.question: What is the response of the people after each curse is proclaimed according to Deuteronomy 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Amen
questions.explanation: Each curse pronounced by the Levites is followed by all the people saying 'Amen' as seen repeatedly in verses 15-26.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 27:7, what were the people to do after offering peace offerings?
options: Eat and rejoice before the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Eat and rejoice before the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:7 commands that after offering peace offerings, the people shall eat and rejoice before the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 27:6 says the altar must be built of whole stones.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:6 clearly instructs that the altar be built of whole stones without any broken ones.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 27:10 commands the people to ignore the statutes given that day.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:10 commands the people to obey the voice of the LORD and do all his commandments and statutes given that day.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 27:26, anyone who does not confirm all the words of this law to do them is cursed.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:26 states that those who do not confirm and obey all the words of the law are cursed.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Deuteronomy 27:5: 'And there shalt thou build an altar unto the LORD thy God, an altar of ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: stones
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:5 instructs to build an altar of stones to the LORD thy God.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 27:18, who is cursed if made to wander out of the way?
questions.correctAnswer: The blind
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:18 pronounces a curse on anyone who causes the blind to wander out of the way.

questions.question: Who spoke to all Israel with a loud voice to pronounce the curses according to Deuteronomy 27:14?
questions.correctAnswer: The Levites
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:14 states that the Levites spoke loudly to all Israel to pronounce the curses.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 27 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 27 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is preparing to enter a new season of life and asks how to maintain faithfulness. Based on Deuteronomy 27, what foundational practice does God command?
options: Keep all the commandments given this day
Build a physical altar at home
Gather in a specific location to pray
questions.correctAnswer: Keep all the commandments given this day
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:1 instructs the people to keep all the commandments given on that day, emphasizing obedience as foundational for faithfulness. This is supported by verses 9-10 and 26 which reinforce obeying God's voice and commandments.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 27 teach us about the importance of publicly proclaiming God’s Law when entering a new phase in life?
options: By setting up stones and writing the law on them
By singing hymns in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By setting up stones and writing the law on them
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 instruct setting up great stones plastered and writing all the words of the law on them when crossing into the promised land. This public declaration helps believers remember and obey God's commands as they enter a new phase.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with integrity at work. Based on Deuteronomy 27, which command speaks directly to honesty and fairness?
options: Cursed be he that removeth his neighbour's landmark
Cursed be he that lieth with his sister
Cursed be he that maketh any graven or molten image
Cursed be he that setteth light by his father or mother
questions.correctAnswer: Cursed be he that removeth his neighbour's landmark
questions.explanation: Verse 17 condemns removing a neighbor's landmark, which symbolizes dishonesty and unfairness in dealings. This teaches believers to act with integrity and respect others' rights, supported by verses 15 and 19 emphasizing fairness.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 27 guide believers in handling family relationships and honoring parents?
options: Cursed be he that setteth light by his father or his mother
Cursed be he that lieth with his mother in law
Cursed be he that removeth his neighbour's landmark
Cursed be he that smiteth his neighbour secretly
questions.correctAnswer: Cursed be he that setteth light by his father or his mother
questions.explanation: Verse 16 clearly teaches the importance of honoring parents, warning against despising them. This supports the biblical virtue of respect and obedience within family life, linking to principles of humility and gratitude.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 27 teach about dealing with temptation in relationships?
options: Cursed be he that lieth with his sister
Cursed be he that offereth peace offerings
Blessed be the man who follows commandments
Cursed be he that removeth his neighbour's landmark
questions.correctAnswer: Cursed be he that lieth with his sister
questions.explanation: Verse 22 condemns incestuous relationships, teaching believers to avoid sexual immorality and maintain purity. This aligns with the broader biblical call to holiness and self-control in relationships.

questions.question: Based on Deuteronomy 27, how can believers cultivate gratitude and joy in their worship practice?
options: By offering peace offerings and eating with rejoicing before the LORD
By fasting without food or drink
By offering only burnt offerings silently
By building altars with iron tools
questions.correctAnswer: By offering peace offerings and eating with rejoicing before the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 7 encourages offering peace offerings and eating with joy before God, highlighting worship as a joyful expression of gratitude. This fosters contentment and fellowship with God and others.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 27 commands that iron tools should be used to build the altar for the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 5 specifically states that no iron tool should be lifted upon the altar stones, emphasizing purity and reverence in construction, symbolizing holiness in service to God.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 27 emphasize the seriousness of obedience to God's law?
options: By pronouncing curses on those who disobey
questions.correctAnswer: By pronouncing curses on those who disobey
questions.explanation: Verses 15-26 contain a series of curses pronounced on those who violate various commandments, highlighting the gravity of disobedience and encouraging wholehearted obedience and reverence.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to maintain unity and encouragement in church life. What does Deuteronomy 27 teach about communal participation in God's commands?
options: All the people shall say, Amen, to the Levites' spoken curses and blessings
Only the priests should respond aloud
Each person should act silently and privately
The elders alone decide on obedience
questions.correctAnswer: All the people shall say, Amen, to the Levites' spoken curses and blessings
questions.explanation: Verses 14-26 show that the Levites speak aloud the curses and the people respond with 'Amen,' fostering communal agreement, accountability, and shared commitment to God's law.

questions.question: How does this passage teach us about stewardship and reverence in worship through the altar construction?
options: Build the altar of whole stones without iron tools
Use whatever materials are most convenient
Build the altar high with metal decoration
Offer gifts only during harvest seasons
questions.correctAnswer: Build the altar of whole stones without iron tools
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 mandate building the altar from whole stones without iron tools, showing reverence and careful stewardship in worship, symbolizing purity and dedication to God’s holiness.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to persevere in faith. Based on Deuteronomy 27, what encouragement about identity can you share?
options: This day you have become the people of the LORD your God
You must earn your place by works
Your identity depends on your family
You are chosen only if perfect
questions.correctAnswer: This day you have become the people of the LORD your God
questions.explanation: Verse 9 affirms the identity of Israel as God's people, encouraging believers to trust God's faithfulness and persevere knowing they belong to Him, which is foundational for spiritual discipline and hope.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 27, believers are free to worship any carved or molten images placed secretly in their homes.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 15 pronounces a curse on anyone who makes and hides graven or molten images, teaching faithfulness to God alone and rejecting idolatry, which is crucial for spiritual integrity.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 27 instruct believers about blessings and curses in relation to obedience?
options: Some tribes stand to bless, others to curse based on obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Some tribes stand to bless, others to curse based on obedience
questions.explanation: Verses 12-14 explain that certain tribes stand on Mount Gerizim to bless and others on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses, underscoring the communal recognition of obedience and disobedience consequences.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 27 commands that when the Israelites have passed over Jordan, they shall set up stones on Mount ______ and plaster them with plaster.
questions.correctAnswer: Ebal
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 8 instruct setting up stones on Mount Ebal and plastering them, symbolizing the public declaration of God's law as they enter the promised land.

questions.question: What practical biblical principle about justice can be learned from the curse against those who pervert judgment of the stranger, fatherless, and widow?
options: Treat all people fairly and protect the vulnerable
Favor relatives over strangers in legal matters
questions.correctAnswer: Treat all people fairly and protect the vulnerable
questions.explanation: Verse 19 condemns perverting judgment against vulnerable groups, teaching believers to uphold justice, fairness, and compassion, reflecting biblical love and integrity.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 27 encourage believers to respond toward God's law and commandments daily?
options: Obey the voice of the LORD and do his commandments
Follow only the parts they like
Ignore the commandments after entering the land
Ask others to obey for them
questions.correctAnswer: Obey the voice of the LORD and do his commandments
questions.explanation: Verse 10 emphasizes the necessity of hearing and obeying God's voice and commandments every day, encouraging consistent obedience as a mark of faith and devotion.

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 27 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 27.

questions.question: What was the purpose of setting up great stones and plastering them upon crossing the Jordan?
options: To write all the words of the law
To build a fortress against enemies
To mark the boundary of Israelite land
questions.correctAnswer: To write all the words of the law
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:2-3 commands the Israelites to set up stones plastered and write all the words of the law upon them when they pass over Jordan.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 27, on which mountain were the stones to be set up and the altar built?
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Ebal
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:4-5 clearly states that the stones and altar were to be set up on Mount Ebal.

questions.question: What was forbidden to be used on the altar constructed on Mount Ebal?
questions.correctAnswer: Iron tools
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:5 prohibits lifting up any iron tool upon the altar, reflecting a cultural and ritual purity concern.

questions.question: Which tribes were appointed to stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people?
options: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, Benjamin
Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, Naphtali
Judah, Reuben, Levi, Simeon, Dan, Naphtali
Joseph, Benjamin, Gad, Asher, Issachar, Zebulun
questions.correctAnswer: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, Benjamin
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:12 lists these six tribes designated to bless the people from Mount Gerizim.

questions.question: Which tribes were designated to stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses?
options: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, Naphtali
Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, Benjamin
Judah, Dan, Asher, Naphtali, Reuben, Gad
Levi, Simeon, Benjamin, Joseph, Issachar, Zebulun
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, Naphtali
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:13 specifically assigns these tribes to stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Levites shouting the curses aloud to all Israel?
options: To publicly affirm the covenant and obedience to the law
To call for a military assembly
questions.correctAnswer: To publicly affirm the covenant and obedience to the law
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:14-26 shows the Levites declaring curses to ensure the people clearly understand the consequences of disobedience, reinforcing covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: Which curse is pronounced for making any graven or molten image and placing it secretly?
options: Cursed be the man that maketh any graven or molten image
Cursed be the man that removeth his neighbour's landmark
Cursed be he that lieth with any manner of beast
Cursed be he that taketh reward to slay an innocent person
questions.correctAnswer: Cursed be the man that maketh any graven or molten image
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:15 pronounces this curse, emphasizing the prohibition of idolatry.

questions.question: The curse pronounced in Deuteronomy 27:19 refers to perverting the judgment of which groups?
questions.correctAnswer: Stranger, fatherless, and widow
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:19 condemns injustice toward vulnerable groups, highlighting social justice themes in the law.

questions.question: Which of the following sexual sins is NOT mentioned in the curses of Deuteronomy 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Lying with a neighbor’s wife
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:20-23 mention sexual sins involving close relatives or beasts but do not explicitly mention lying with a neighbor's wife.

questions.question: True or False: The altar on Mount Ebal was to be built with whole stones and no iron tools used.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:5-6 specifies the altar must be made of whole stones and no iron tools should be used on them.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'land that floweth with milk and honey' as used in Deuteronomy 27?
options: It typifies the abundance and blessing promised by God
It describes the climate of the land in literal terms
It was a common phrase for desert lands
It was a metaphor for hardship and struggle
questions.correctAnswer: It typifies the abundance and blessing promised by God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:3 uses this phrase to symbolize the fertility and blessing of the Promised Land, a motif echoed in Exodus and Numbers.

questions.question: Which command in Deuteronomy 27 emphasizes social justice and care for vulnerable people?
options: Cursed be he that perverteth the judgment of the stranger, fatherless, and widow
Cursed be he that setteth light by his father or his mother
Cursed be he that removeth his neighbour's landmark
Cursed be he that lieth with his sister
questions.correctAnswer: Cursed be he that perverteth the judgment of the stranger, fatherless, and widow
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:19 highlights the importance of justice for vulnerable groups, a theme consistent throughout the Pentateuch.

questions.question: How does the division of tribes between Mount Gerizim and Mount Ebal reflect a broader biblical literary structure?
options: It creates a chiastic structure with blessings and curses
It reflects a historical battle formation
It shows tribal favoritism by Moses
It is a random geographical assignment
questions.correctAnswer: It creates a chiastic structure with blessings and curses
questions.explanation: The arrangement of tribes on Mount Gerizim (blessings) and Mount Ebal (curses) reflects a chiastic literary device emphasizing covenant obedience and consequences.

questions.question: What does the repeated phrase 'And all the people shall say, Amen' signify in the context of Deuteronomy 27 curses?
questions.correctAnswer: Communal agreement and covenant ratification
questions.explanation: The phrase in Deuteronomy 27:15-26 indicates collective assent to the covenant obligations and consequences.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the theme of blessings and cursings associated with obedience to the law as seen in Deuteronomy 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Galatians 3:10-14
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:10-14 discusses the curse of the law and blessing through faith, echoing the blessings and cursings motif from Deuteronomy 27.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Moses and the priests the Levites said, 'Take heed, and hearken, O Israel; this day thou art become the people of the ______ thy God.'
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:9 states that Israel became the people of the LORD thy God, emphasizing covenant identity.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 27 commands the people to confirm only parts of the law for their obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:26 pronounces a curse on anyone who does not confirm all the words of the law to do them, emphasizing full obedience.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 27 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 27 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the purpose of setting up great stones and plastering them as commanded in Deuteronomy 27?
options: To write all the words of the law upon them
To build a house for the LORD
To mark the boundary of the land
questions.correctAnswer: To write all the words of the law upon them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:2-3 instructs the Israelites to set up great stones and plaster them so that all the words of the law could be written plainly on them. This served as a public declaration of God's covenant. Similarly, in Exodus 24:12, God gave Moses the tablets of the covenant law, and in Psalm 119:11, the law is treasured in the heart to avoid sin. In the New Testament, Jesus affirms the law's authority (Matthew 5:17), and Paul emphasizes obedience to God's word (Romans 2:13).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 27, where were the stones and altar to be set up after crossing the Jordan?
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Ebal
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:4-5 commands the people to set up the stones and build the altar on Mount Ebal after crossing the Jordan. This location was significant for covenant renewal. Mount Gerizim is mentioned in the next verses as the place of blessing (Deut 27:12). The significance of sacred mountains is echoed in Exodus 19:20 and Hebrews 12:18. The altar built without iron tools (Deut 27:5) symbolizes purity, consistent with other altar instructions (Exodus 20:25).

questions.question: What type of stones were to be used to build the altar according to the command in Deuteronomy 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Whole stones
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:6 specifies that the altar must be built of whole stones, without breaking them, symbolizing completeness and holiness. This mirrors the instruction in Exodus 20:25 and reflects the theme of purity in worship. The use of unbroken stones prefigures Christ's sinless sacrifice (1 Peter 1:19) and the call to offer ourselves as living stones in spiritual worship (1 Peter 2:5).

questions.question: Who were to stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people after crossing the Jordan?
options: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin
Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali
questions.correctAnswer: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:12 designates these six tribes to stand on Mount Gerizim to pronounce blessings. This division of tribes into groups for blessings and curses reflects God's covenant blessings and judgments (Deut 27:13). The blessings correspond to obedience and covenant faithfulness, themes prevalent in Leviticus 26 and reiterated by Jesus in the Beatitudes (Matthew 5:3-12).

questions.question: Which group of tribes was assigned to stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses?
options: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali
Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:13 lists these tribes to stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses on covenant breakers. This public declaration of curses is a warning against sin and disobedience, consistent with covenant theology seen in Leviticus 26 and Deuteronomy 28. The pronouncement of curses reveals God's holiness and justice, themes echoed in Proverbs 3:33 and Galatians 3:10.

questions.question: What does the repeated phrase 'And all the people shall say, Amen' signify in the context of Deuteronomy 27?
options: Communal agreement and solemn acceptance of the covenant curses
A ritual chant to ward off evil spirits
An invitation to celebrate the law
questions.correctAnswer: Communal agreement and solemn acceptance of the covenant curses
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 27:15-26, after each curse, the people respond 'Amen,' signifying their solemn agreement and acknowledgment of the covenant consequences. This communal affirmation emphasizes corporate responsibility and covenant obedience, a key biblical theme (Numbers 14:28; Nehemiah 8:6). The New Testament encourages believers to affirm God’s word with sincere hearts (Romans 1:5; 1 Corinthians 14:16).

questions.question: Which sin is specifically cursed in Deuteronomy 27 for making a graven or molten image and hiding it?
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry and deception
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:15 curses anyone who makes an idol and hides it, condemning secret idolatry and deception. This reflects God's command against idolatry throughout Scripture (Exodus 20:4-5; Isaiah 44:9-20) and highlights the holiness of God who demands exclusive worship (1 Corinthians 10:14). Jesus reiterates this when teaching against idols of the heart (Matthew 6:24).

questions.question: Which command is linked to the curse pronounced on someone who 'removeth his neighbour's landmark'?
options: Respect for others’ property and justice
questions.correctAnswer: Respect for others’ property and justice
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:17 pronounces a curse on anyone who removes a neighbor’s boundary marker, violating justice and property rights. This upholds God’s justice and neighbor-love commands (Leviticus 19:14; Proverbs 22:28). Jesus teaches the principle of loving one’s neighbor (Matthew 22:39), and the New Testament calls for respect of others’ possessions (Ephesians 4:28).

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 27, what is the consequence for perverting the judgment of the stranger, fatherless, and widow?
questions.correctAnswer: Being cursed by the people
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:19 curses anyone who perverts justice for the vulnerable—strangers, orphans, and widows—highlighting God's concern for justice and protection of the weak (Psalm 82:3-4; Isaiah 1:17). This theme is echoed in the New Testament (James 1:27) emphasizing care for marginalized groups as integral to true religion.

questions.question: Which of the following sexual sins is NOT mentioned in the curses listed in Deuteronomy 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Lying with his mother's sister
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:20-23 lists several forbidden sexual relations, including lying with a father's wife, sister, mother-in-law, and beasts, but does not mention lying with a mother's sister. This reflects the biblical emphasis on sexual holiness (Leviticus 18) and God's design for marriage. The New Testament upholds these moral standards (1 Corinthians 6:9-10).

questions.question: What is the reason given for the curse on the man who lies with his father's wife in Deuteronomy 27?
options: Because he uncovereth his father's skirt
questions.correctAnswer: Because he uncovereth his father's skirt
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:20 states the curse is because the man 'uncovereth his father's skirt,' a metaphor for violating family honor and covenant boundaries. This illustrates God's design for family purity and respect (Leviticus 18:8). Such prohibitions highlight God's holiness and order, echoed in the New Testament's calls for sexual purity (Hebrews 13:4).

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 27 command about the use of iron tools on the altar stones?
options: No iron tool is to be lifted upon them
Only iron tools are to be used
Iron tools must be consecrated first
The altar must be made entirely of iron
questions.correctAnswer: No iron tool is to be lifted upon them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:5 forbids the use of iron tools on the altar stones, signifying the altar's sanctity and purity. This prohibition is found in Exodus 20:25 and symbolizes that the altar is dedicated to God, untainted by human weapons or instruments of death. This foreshadows Christ's pure and unblemished sacrifice (1 Peter 1:19).

questions.question: What was the purpose of the peace offerings mentioned in Deuteronomy 27 after building the altar?
options: To eat and rejoice before the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: To eat and rejoice before the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:7 instructs offering peace offerings followed by eating and rejoicing before the LORD, signifying fellowship and celebration of covenant relationship. This reflects God's desire for joyful communion with His people (Psalm 100:2; Isaiah 55:12). The New Testament also portrays the Lord's Supper as a joyful remembrance of Christ's peace (1 Corinthians 10:16-17).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 27, what is the ultimate consequence for someone who does not confirm all the words of the law and do them?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be cursed
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:26 pronounces a curse on anyone who does not confirm and obey all the words of the law, underscoring the seriousness of covenant obedience. This principle is echoed in Galatians 3:10 and James 2:10, emphasizing that breaking any part of the law brings judgment. It reflects God's holiness and the need for repentance and faith in Christ for salvation (Romans 3:23-24).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by Moses declaring 'this day thou art become the people of the LORD thy God' in Deuteronomy 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Covenant identity and election
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:9-10 highlights Israel's covenant identity as God's chosen people, emphasizing election and obedience to God's commandments. This theme permeates Scripture (Exodus 19:5-6; Isaiah 43:20-21) and is foundational to understanding God's redemptive plan culminating in Christ (1 Peter 2:9). The call to obedience reflects God's holiness and covenant faithfulness (Hebrews 8:10).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the role of the Levites in Deuteronomy 27 during the pronouncement of curses?
options: They spoke aloud the curses to the people
They led the tribes in blessing on Mount Gerizim
They wrote the law on the stones
questions.correctAnswer: They spoke aloud the curses to the people
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 27:14 states that the Levites were to speak aloud the curses to all Israel. This role as mediators and teachers of the law reflects their priestly function (Numbers 3:5-10). Their proclamation of curses serves as a public warning against sin, consistent with prophetic calls to repentance (Jeremiah 7:25). The New Testament continues this priestly mediation through Christ (Hebrews 7:26-28).
